content.text: Measure and record the length \(l\) of the pendulum

Place the metre rule on the bench so that the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark is vertically below the centre of the pendulum bob. Describe how you judge that the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark is vertically below the centre of the pendulum bob. You may draw a diagram
Pull the pendulum bob to one side until it is vertically above the 52.0 cm mark
the rule. Release the pendulum bob, then measure and record in Table 1
time \(t\) taken for 10 complete swings of the pendulum. The distance \(d\) that the pendulum bob was moved is recorded in the first column of the table
Calculate the period \(T\) of the pendulum. The period \(T\) is the time taken for one complete swing of the pendulum
Repeat steps (i) and (ii) using \(d\) values of 3.0 cm, 4.0 cm, 5.0 cm and 6.0 cm
Complete the column headings in the table
Using the evidence in the table, describe the effect on the period \(T\) of increasing the distance \(d\). Justify your answer by reference to your results
description
justification
Explain briefly why it is sensible to measure the time taken for ten swings of the pendulum rather than one
[Total: 10]
In this experiment, you will investigate a pendulum
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1. The apparatus has been set up you
Do not adjust the length of the pendulum or the position of the clamp
Measure and record room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
Pour \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water supplied into the beaker. Place the thermometer in the beaker of water
Measure and record the temperature \(\theta_{0}\) of the water
Start the stopclock and record the temperature \(\theta_{1}\) of the water at time \(t = 100 \text{s}\)

Calculate the temperature difference \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\) between \(\theta_{0}\) and room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}} = (\theta_{0} - \theta_{\mathrm{R}})\)
Calculate the temperature fall \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) of the hot water using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}} = (\theta_{0} - \theta_{1})\)
Measure and record the temperature \(\theta_{2}\) of the warm water
Start the stopclock and record the temperature \(\theta_{3}\) of the water at time \(t = 100 \text{s}\)

Calculate the temperature difference \(\theta_{\mathrm{B}}\) between \(\theta_{2}\) and room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{B}} = (\theta_{2} - \theta_{\mathrm{R}})\)
Calculate the temperature fall \(\theta_{\mathrm{W}}\) of the warm water using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{W}} = (\theta_{2} - \theta_{3})\)
Empty the beaker. Pour \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water supplied into the beaker. Add of the water at room temperature to the beaker. Briefly stir the water

A student suggests that the rate of temperature change is proportional to the difference between the starting temperature and room temperature. This can be expressed as \(\frac{\theta_{\mathrm{A}}}{\theta_{\mathrm{H}}} = \frac{\theta_{\mathrm{B}}}{\theta_{\mathrm{W}}}\)
State whether your results support this suggestion and justify your answer with reference to the results
statement
justification
If this experiment were to be repeated in order to check the results, it would be important to control the conditions
Suggest two such conditions that should be controlled
In this experiment, you will investigate the rate of cooling of water
You are provided with a supply of hot water and a supply of water at room temperature. Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 2.1
Switch on. Measure and record the current \(I_{\mathrm{S}}\) in the lamps and the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{S}}\) across the three lamps. Switch off
Calculate the combined resistance \(R_{\mathrm{S}}\) of the lamps using the equation \(R_{\mathrm{S}} = \frac{V_{\mathrm{S}}}{I_{\mathrm{S}}}\)
Switch on. Measure and record the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\) across the comb of lamps
Measure and record the current \(I_{1}\). Switch off
Move the ammeter to position 2 as shown in Fig. 3.2. Switch on. Measure and record the current \(I_{2}\). Switch off
Move the ammeter to position 3 as shown in Fig. 3.2. Switch on. Measure and record the current \(I_{3}\). Switch off
Calculate the total current \(I_{\mathrm{C}}\) using the equation \(I_{\mathrm{C}} = I_{2} + I_{3}\)
Calculate the total resistance \(R_{\mathrm{p}}\) of the combination of the lamps, using the equation \(R_{\mathrm{p}} = \frac{V_{\mathrm{p}}}{I_{1}}\)
Rearrange the circuit as shown in Fig. 3.2. The ammeter is in position 1
A student decides to investigate the effect on \(R_{\mathrm{p}}\) of changing the current \(I_{1}\) , using a variable resistor (rheostat)
In the space below, copy the diagram shown in Fig. 3.2, but with the addition of a variable resistor connected in the circuit at a suitable position for the investigation
In this experiment, you will investigate current and potential difference using lamps in and parallel circuits
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Figs. 3.1 and 3.2. The circuit shown in Fig. 3.1 is set up for you
Measure, and record in Table 4.1, the distance \(v\) between the centre of the lens and the screen
Calculate \(uv\) and enter the value in the table
Measure, and record in the table, the distance \(d\) between the illuminated object and the screen
Place the lens a distance \(u = 30.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object. Move the screen until a sharply focused image of the object is seen on the screen
Repeat the steps in (a) using \(u\) values of \(45.0 \text{cm}\), \(50.0 \text{cm}\), \(55.0 \text{cm}\) and \(60.0 \text{cm}\)
Plot a graph of \(uv / \text{cm}^2\) ( \(y\)-axis) against \(d / \text{cm}\) ( \(x\)-axis). You do **not** need to be exact at the origin (0,0)
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
State a value for the focal length \(f\) of the lens, giving your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment
[Total: 10]
The gradient of the graph is numerically equal to the focal length of the lens
In this experiment, you will determine the focal length of a lens
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 4.1
